description: Analyzing continuity and change within the Lutheran tradition, students consider
Luther's theology and proposals for the reform of Catholicism and evaluate major
reappraisals of Lutheran beliefs and practices that developed in response to new issues
and social situations. Topics include Orthodoxy and Pietism, conservative and liberal
responses to the Enlightenment, modern European Lutheranism and issues of particular
importance to Lutheranism in Scandinavia, America, and developing countries.  Offered
periodically during Interim. Also counts toward German studies concentration. Prerequisite: BTS-B.
